titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Frey Family Papers, 1790-1917.
titlestmt.author: Pamela Cooley

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid created with EADitor by user nycoofam.
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

acqinfo.p: Purchase; Frank M. Thomas; 1953; NM-086.53, NM-087.53.
Gift; Dr. Charles K. Winne, Jr.; NM-003.77.

relatedmaterial.p: Referenced in, National Historical Publications Commission, Philip M. Hamer, ed., "A Guide to Archives and Manuscripts in the United States" (New Haven, Yale University Press: 1961), p. 383.

accessrestrict.p: Coll. No. 161, Frey Family Papers is open for research according to the regulations of Fenimore Art Museum Library.

bioghist.p: Helen Ludlow of the Hampton Institute in Virginia taught freed slaves.Caroline Frey was a student in the Poughkeepsie Female Academy, 1857-1858. She married Col. G.R. Giddings in 1862. They lived at various military posts in Connecticut, Louisiana, Ohio, and Wisconsin.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of the papers of the Frey family and related Ludlow and Baldwin families of Kinderhook, Columbia County; Oswego, Oswego County; and Palatine Bridge, Montgomery County, N.Y. It includes family correspondence, diaries, farm and legal documents, letter books, daguerreotypes, photograph albums, historical manuscripts of Samuel Frey Ludlow, and a eulogy and picture of Fitz Hugh Ludlow.

Among the letters are those of Helen Ludlow relating her experiences educating freed slaves; of Caroline Freyher concerning her years as a student, her marriage, and her life at various military posts; of Henry Ludlow; and of Marie Tappen. Additionally, there are letters from Anna Wendell, Albany, N.Y., to Caroline Ludlow.
